content.question: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure shows a two row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in years.” The heading for row 2 is “A of t, in hundred pounds per year.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. A of t is 163. Column 2. t is 10. A of t is 142. Column 3. t is 22. A of t is 124. Column 4. t is 30. A of t is 118. Column 5. t is 40. A of t is 113." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid solid solid solid solid none" frame="solid" rowlines="solid solid none"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(years)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>22</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>30</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>40</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>A</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(hundred pounds per year)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>163</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>142</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>124</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>118</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>113</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math> The amount of nitrogen in a particular river is affected by two sources. Nitrogen from the first source enters the river at a rate modeled by the decreasing, differentiable function <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Selected values of <math alttext="A of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. Nitrogen from the second source enters the river at a rate modeled by the function <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined by <math alttext="B of t equals, 20 plus, open parenthesis, the fraction with numerator 95, and denominator 1 plus the cube root of t, end fraction, close parenthesis, raised to the 1.25 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mroot><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mroot></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1.25</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Both <math alttext="A of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are measured in hundreds of pounds of nitrogen per year, and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in years for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Using a right Riemann sum with the four subintervals indicated by the data in the table, approximate the total amount of nitrogen from the first source that enters the river over the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is this approximation an overestimate or an underestimate? Give a reason for your answer.

frqParts.text: A GRAPHING CALCULATOR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS QUESTION.You are permitted to use your calculator to solve an equation, find the derivative of a function at a point, or calculate the value of a definite integral. However, you must clearly indicate the setup of your question, namely the equation, function, or integral you are using. If you use other built-in features or programs, you must show the mathematical steps necessary to produce your results. Your work must be expressed in standard mathematical notation rather than calculator syntax.Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. <math alttext="The figure shows a two row table with 5 columns of data. The heading for row 1 is “t, in years.” The heading for row 2 is “A of t, in hundred pounds per year.” The data in the table are as follows. Column 1. t is 0. A of t is 163. Column 2. t is 10. A of t is 142. Column 3. t is 22. A of t is 124. Column 4. t is 30. A of t is 118. Column 5. t is 40. A of t is 113." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtable columnlines="solid solid solid solid solid none" frame="solid" rowlines="solid solid none"><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>t</mi></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(years)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>0</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>10</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>22</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>30</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>40</mn></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtable><mtr><mtd><mi>A</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi>t</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd><mtext>(hundred pounds per year)</mtext></mtd></mtr></mtable></mtd><mtd><mn>163</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>142</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>124</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>118</mn></mtd><mtd><mn>113</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></math> The amount of nitrogen in a particular river is affected by two sources. Nitrogen from the first source enters the river at a rate modeled by the decreasing, differentiable function <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Selected values of <math alttext="A of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown in the table above. Nitrogen from the second source enters the river at a rate modeled by the function <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> defined by <math alttext="B of t equals, 20 plus, open parenthesis, the fraction with numerator 95, and denominator 1 plus the cube root of t, end fraction, close parenthesis, raised to the 1.25 power" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mroot><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mroot></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>1.25</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Both <math alttext="A of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are measured in hundreds of pounds of nitrogen per year, and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is measured in years for <math alttext="0 less than or equal to t, less than or equal to 40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) Using a right Riemann sum with the four subintervals indicated by the data in the table, approximate the total amount of nitrogen from the first source that enters the river over the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Is this approximation an overestimate or an underestimate? Give a reason for your answer.

(b) Find <math alttext="B prime of 39" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>39</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. Using correct units, interpret the meaning of <math alttext="B prime of 39" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>39</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of the problem.

(c) Based on model <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, find the average rate, in hundreds of pounds per year, at which nitrogen from the second source enters the river during the time interval <math alttext="5 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) Using model <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and your approximation from part (a), find an approximation for the total combined amount of nitrogen from the two sources that enters the river over the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than or equal to t, is less than or equal to 40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Give your answer to the nearest hundred pounds.

topic.text: 2.3: Estimating Derivatives of a Function at a Point

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
